title: Technology designed for monitoring astronauts is helping save the lives of air ambulance patients
text:
Technology designed for astronauts is helping save the lives of air ambulance patients.

Until recently, paramedics had to use radios to provide doctors with details of a patient’s condition and what might be needed to help them.

But under a test scheme in Kent, Surrey and Sussex, patients are hooked up to a monitoring device which continuously beams data such as heart rate and blood pressure to medics back at the hospital so they can better prepare.

Paramedics had to use radios to provide doctors with details of a patient’s condition and what might be needed to help them (file image)

The technology designed for astronauts includes a monitoring device which continuously beams data such as heart rate and blood pressure to medics back at the hospital so they can better prepare. Pictured, NASA astronauts replacing the Space Station's Solar Array Batteries

The system was created by UK firm Philips Remote Diagnostic Technologies with the European Space Agency. Professor Richard Lyon, of the Air Ambulance Charity, said it had already had a ‘meaningful impact’ on at least five patients.
description: Technology designed for astronauts is helping save the lives of air ambulance patients. The test scheme is being implemented in Kent, Surrey and Sussex and patients are hooked to a monitoring device.
